headline: Ohio Redistricting Commission is assembling the new team of mapmakers
author: Andy Chow | Statehouse News Bureau
sentences:
< < Back to
COLUMBUS, Ohio (Statehouse News Bureau) — The Ohio Redistricting Commission will include two mediators from the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit to help settle disputes as Republican and Democratic mapmakers try to create new district maps for the state House and Senate.
“I don’t think anyone knows whether we’re going to be successful in this, we’re certainly going to try to be successful, we’re doing something different that we have not done in the past.
They join a mapmaking team that already includes two experts with the Republican legislative caucus, two experts with the Democratic legislative caucus, and two outside consultants.
By doing that I think we’re certainly moving forward but in the next couple of days we’re going start to see whether this gels or if it does not gel,” said DeWine.
Mapmakers are directed to follow the state constitution’s requirements on redistricting and the court’s three previous orders on state legislative district maps.
This is will be the commission’s fourth attempt at adopting a map after the first three were found unconstitutional by the Ohio Supreme Court.
Meanwhile, the Democratic members of the commission have filed a motion asking the Ohio Supreme Court to delay the May 3 primary.
Johnson and McDonald are expected to appear before the commission on Wednesday and to fill out a conflicts disclosure form.
Mike DeWine (R-Ohio) says the commission hopes the mediators can be neutral players that can bring all the sides together.
The commission decided Monday to bring in Douglas Johnson and Michael McDonald as the outside consultants.
The commission voted unanimously to approve the two mediators, Catherine C. Geyer and Scott Coburn.
The commission has until March 28 to adopt a new set of maps for the Ohio House and Ohio Senate.
